text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with red curry flank steak i love
red curry beef one of my favorite Thai
delicacies
so I was thinking will those flavors
work for a marinade for flank steak and
the answer oh yeah totally worked so
here's what I did I took a shallow pan
here that I'm going to marinate my meat
I added some fish sauce some rice
vinegar
you'll also notice no soy no salt
there's enough salt in the fish sauce
and the rice vinegar to season this
garlic of course some hot sauce that is
sriracha some red curry powder that's
McCormick right off the shelf red curry
powder and then red curry paste again
right from the supermarket shelf
I think it's Taste of Thai or Thai taste
or whatever you you know it's like the
only Thai ingredient in the supermarket
you should be able to find all that
stuff and last but not least some ginger
now I normally would just grate fresh
ginger like a tablespoon or so I had a
ginger puree leftover from a recipe
which is just pure ginger in a tube so I
use that we're going to give that a
whisk I'm going to throw in my flank
steak and those are usually sold in the
market already trimmed but if it has
silver skin on there you'll have to just
take a little bit of that off but most
of them are ready to use as this one was
or I'm going to toss that and I'm also
gonna poke it with my fork to make lots
of little holes for the marinade to get
in alright I'm going to let that sit it
room temperature for one hour and I'm
going to toss that a few times during
that period and you're thinking is that
safe I think so I mean don't quote me on
it but I think it's safe meat should be
room temperature when you grill it
anyway and that actually is a way to
quick marinade things marinate at room
temperature much faster than
refrigerated probably something to do
with science you can also put that in
the refrigerator for three or four hours
really get the same result
out to the grill now this doesn't have
any oil on it so I made sure I had a
nice season grill very hot I rubbed it
with some oil I'm going to grill that
for about six seven minutes per side for
medium now another flavor component of
red beef curry is basil usually Thai
basil but I have a really nice basil
plant in the backyard that needed some
trimming so I thought why not put the
basil on the top each time I turn it to
sort of send the meat with that basil
aroma all right not a super strong
flavor very subtle just a hint of
aroma of basil and basil is a fairly
important component to finish a red beef
curry stew so that's where I got that
idea don't do it if you don't want to do
it and by the way if you can find Thai
basil use that much more intense and I
know oh you're not supposed to play with
your meat how come you play with your
meat so much Chef John first of all stop
giggling
second of all here where I have a reason
to turn it a couple times I am Not
Afraid sure a steak put it down turn it
once you're done fine
but if you need to turn your meat a
couple times don't worry it's fine relax
you should only believe about 65% of
what you hear on Food Network okay
that's a rough estimate once it was done
I pulled it off
no shame use a thermometer all right one
31 32 ish for a medium I think is
perfect for flank I do not like flank
steak cooked too rare it gets chewy I
think most people will enjoy the texture
at medium much better let it rest at
least 10 minutes slice across the grain
you know what that means right
across the grain and there you go
unbelievable incredibly juicy it has a
similar flavor profile to a red beef
curry just really beautiful flavor I was
so so happy with this recipe and you
know I know you guys you're going to
tailor this to your own personal taste
as you should anyway I hope you give
that a try go to the site all the
ingredients are there and as always
enjoy
